Comment: This really is a problem with renewables. Unlike traditional generators they don’t store kinetic energy in giant rotating turbine rotors which can pump energy back in the event of a generator or transmission failure, at least for a few seconds or minutes to give the grid operators time to stabilize the frequency by bringing more generators online or (worst case) load shedding.  They call it spinning reserve. Now sure you could have reserve capacity with renewables and chemical batteries, molten salt, flywheels, etc. but it would require *massive* investment to get anything close to the capacity of conventional generators where it’s inherent to the design.
